header.title: METATRON AND THE TREASURE OF GOLD: NOTES ON A DREAM INQUIRY TEXT FROM THE CAIRO GENIZAH
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Jewish Magic, Historical Analysis

central_thesis: The article aims to correct the misclassification of a Cairo Genizah fragment (F1908.440) previously labeled as a 'charm,' re-identifying it as a unique and rare example of a Jewish dream inquiry text from the 11th century. It provides historical and practical context for Jewish dream inquiry practices, specifically detailing an adjuration to Metatron for the discovery of hidden gold treasure.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the ancient perception of dreams as meaningful divine messages, noting the challenge of interpretation. It contrasts the biblical stance, which generally favors direct prophecy over 'riddle dreams' requiring interpretation, and explores the diverse, often contradictory, rabbinic views on dreams, including beliefs in their validity, practices for reversing bad dreams (hatavat halom), and the idea that dreams 'follow the mouth' (interpretation).

This part delves into historical dream inquiry methods. It highlights explicit rabbinic evidence, though rare and often categorized as prohibited 'ways of the Amorites' (e.g., kissing coffins, turning garments, sitting on brooms). The discussion then broadens to Greco-Roman magical practices involving adjurations to heavenly beings for dream revelations, and later Jewish mystical traditions (Hekhalot and Merkavah literature) which include detailed instructions for inducing angelic appearances in dreams. It also presents R. Hai Gaon's skeptical yet informative responsum and Maimonides' distinction between necromancy (condemned) and angelic prophecy (a high stage).

structure_content.chapter_title: Şedaqah, Metatron and the Gold Coins: A Dream Inquiry Adjuration from the Cairo Genizah
structure_content.summary: This section focuses on the specific Cairo Genizah fragment F1908.440, dating to the 11th century, which is an actual implementation of a dream inquiry. The text, believed to have been prepared for a man named Şedaqah, adjures the archangel Metatron to reveal the location of hidden gold coins. The author contrasts this practical magical evidence with high-intellectual views, emphasizing its 'insider' perspective on medieval Jewish daily life and magical utility, especially for economic gain.

structure_content.chapter_title: Textual Analysis of F1908.440 (Recto and Verso)
structure_content.summary: A detailed, line-by-line analysis and translation of the amulet text are provided. The analysis highlights the unique linguistic features and orthography, indicative of Babylonian pronunciation, and compares it with parallel Metatron adjurations from other Genizah amulets. The text, though grammatically imperfect, explicitly invokes YHVH and Metatron, detailing Metatron's exalted titles and responsibilities (e.g., 'high priest,' 'head of the (heavenly) camps') before requesting the revelation of the gold coins' location to both the practitioner and his mother. The inscription is identified as a performative text, its efficacy being its primary measure.

key_concepts.definition: An intentional magical practice to gain concealed knowledge, often for practical purposes like finding treasure, by inducing specific dreams through rituals and adjurations to divine or angelic entities.
A specific method of dream inquiry where one sleeps in a sacred or 'pure' place after ritual preparation, hoping to receive a message or vision in a dream from a deity or spirit.

A principal archangel in Jewish mysticism, invoked in the analyzed Genizah amulet. He is depicted with titles such as 'prince of princes,' 'high priest,' and 'head of the heavenly camps,' acting as a messenger of 'God’s thoughts' for revelations.

A ritualistic command or invocation, often using divine names or epithets, to compel a spiritual entity (e.g., an angel or demon) to perform a specific action or reveal information within a magical practice.

A collection of Jewish manuscript fragments discovered in the Ben Ezra Synagogue in Fustat, Old Cairo, providing a unique and extensive insight into Jewish life, culture, and magical practices from the 10th to 19th centuries, including 'insider' evidence of magic previously known only through hostile external accounts.

A rabbinic legal category referring to customs and practices considered idolatrous or superstitious, and thus forbidden to Jews. Some dream-inducing rituals were historically categorized under this prohibition.

practical_system.description: The practical system is a 'dream inquiry' method designed to uncover hidden treasures (gold coins) by adjuring the archangel Metatron to appear in a dream and reveal the precise location. It involves meticulous ritual preparation and the use of a written magical text placed under the head during sleep.
tools: A written adjuration text (the amulet F1908.440 is an example) inscribed on a durable material (e.g., deer hide, paper).
A 'pure place' for sleeping, implying ritual cleanliness and separation.
Knowledge of specific divine and angelic names, epithets, and scriptural verses for recitation.
rituals: Fasting for a specific period (e.g., three continuous days, or two days and one night) before the inquiry.
Purification of the practitioner and the sleeping place, including wearing pure, clean, washed clothes, avoiding dirt, and possibly abstaining from contact with women.
Praying throughout the day of the ritual and reciting specific incantations before falling asleep.
Writing a detailed adjuration text, invoking YHVH and Metatron by his numerous titles, on a physical medium (such as deer hide or a small paper sheet).
Placing the written adjuration under the head (pillow) before going to sleep in a 'pure place.'
Observing ethical guidelines post-revelation: if Metatron explicitly forbids revealing the information, it must be concealed. If silent on concealment, the information may be shared.

relevant_quotes.text: The aim of what follows is to correct their error and expose the real essence of the text—a rare case of the execution of a dream inquiry.
Through these practices certain required knowledge was sought that would hopefully be revealed during sleep.

Magical practices for dream revelation—that is, the application of ritual means of adjurations and gestures to subdue a heavenly being into appearing in a dream and revealing to the dreamer any desired (concealed) matter—were employed in the Greco-Roman world.

I adjure you the great prince who is appointed over the great princes in the Ineffable Name that you will show me the place of the gold coins and I shall not forget it completely truly, and reveal it to me.

This archangel, who seems to be summoned to the dream as a messenger of 'God's thoughts' rather than as an autonomous source of knowledge, is depicted not only as 'the prince of princes...appointed over the great princes...head of the (heavenly) camps,' but also as 'high priest, head of the priests.'

Oh Metatron Oh, he is beloved and dear over all the dwellers of height, a faithful servant of God of Israel, high priest, head of the priests. You have seventy names, you are appointed over the great princes and you are the head of the (heavenly) camps

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is highly relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism as it meticulously details a practical magical system from medieval Jewish tradition, correcting scholarly misunderstandings and providing rare 'insider' textual evidence. It illuminates the historical continuity of dream inquiry, angelic adjuration, and economic magic, placing these practices within their broader cultural and religious contexts, and comparing them to contemporaneous and earlier Jewish and Greco-Roman traditions. The focus on Metatron, a key figure in Jewish mysticism, further links this to Qabalistic and Hermetic traditions where angelic hierarchies are central.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers in Jewish studies, history of magic, religious studies, and Western Esotericism; practitioners of ceremonial magic, Qabalah, and grimoire traditions interested in historical precedents and operative mechanics of angelic invocation and divination for practical outcomes.
